thread.title: 7 things to know about today, plus how Orlando scores for housing market health
thread.title_full: 7 things to know about today, plus how Orlando scores for housing market health

author: Cindy Barth
title: 7 things to know about today, plus how Orlando scores for housing market health
text: 7 things to know about today, plus how Orlando scores for housing market health Aug 27, 2015, 7:06am EDT Updated Aug 27, 2015, 7:10am EDT Industries & Tags Cindy Barth Editor Orlando Business Journal Home of the Day Enlarge Kriss Russell Orlando came in at No. 227 out of 300 in the 2015 healthiest housing markets rankings by… more Ever wondered which city has the healthiest housing market in the U.S. right now? Well, you're in luck because WalletHub has come up with such a list. The rankings are based on 14 metrics, including the percentage of homes with negative equity, average number of days on the market, foreclosure rates, building permit activity, home price as a percentage of income, job growth and population growth. And the healthiest housing market is ... drum roll, please ... Frisco, Texas. Yeah, I don't know where that is, either. As for Florida metros, well, we didn't score so well among the 300 cities on the list. Boca Raton was the top-ranking Florida metro at No. 194. Orlando came in at No. 227, Tampa No. 230, Miami No. 238 and Jacksonville No. 281. Check out the rankings here . Oh, and if you're still curious about Frisco, Texas, click here . And be sure to check out these other Thursday headlines: Port OKs $90M for terminal upgrades Port Canaveral commissioners green-lighted a $90 million financing plan for upgrades to Cruise Terminals 5 and 10 in order to accommodate larger ships and a new 700-car parking garage at Terminal 5, Florida Today reports. The cruise terminal renovations will be handled by Haskell of Jacksonville, the parking garage by Ivey's Construction Inc. of Merritt Island and passenger boarding bridges by Adelete of Barcelona, Spain. Read more here . Cruise business at Port Canaveral is a huge tourism driver for Central Florida. Millions of tourists travel to the region each year for cruise vacations, many of which extend their stays onto land in Orlando. Want to learn how to pitch a TV show concept? Hit Maker Summit can help The Hit Maker Summit, a TV pitch crash course produced by SellYourTvConceptNow.com and held in Orlando every fall, will be back again Sept. 19-21 with an interesting lineup of speakers/coaches. Confirmed speakers include: Doug Stanley , Emmy-winning producer of Deadliest Catch and CEO of Ridgeline Entertainment; Kim Dawson , former Showtime network executive and producer of The Mickey Mouse Club for Disney, Making the Band for ABC, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 1 , 2 and 3 and more; Eddie Pittman, writer for Disney’s hit series Phineas and Ferb ; Wayne Carter, screenwriter for HBO, CBS, Universal, Fox, Universal, National Lampoon and others; Tracy Frenkel, Second City alum, producer and actor for Nickelodeon, HBO and NBC; and Hit Maker Summit co-founders Mark and Jeanne Simon. Check it out here www.HitMakerSummit.com . Greenspoon Marder adds government practice Greenspoon Marder Law has added a government practice to its Orlando office. The new five-lawyer team is headed by attorney Usher (Larry) Brown, who currently serves as city attorney for Winter Park and is also the Osceola County School Board attorney. The addition of the new practice underscores Greenspoon's growth in Orlando in the past two years, nearly doubling its number of lawyers and support personnel, and going from occupying one to two floors at the Capital Plaza building at 201 E. Pine St. Statewide, the firm has has added more niche practices such as entertainment law — the firm represents Pitbull — and an alcohol division. Mariner's Village sold for $15.5M The 133,400-square-foot Mariner's Village in Orlando has been bought by a private, South American investment group for $15.5 million. The Shopping Center Group represented the seller, an affiliate of Madison Marquette, in the transaction that closed on July 31. “We have seen considerable private investor interest in our marketing of several Winn Dixie-anchored shopping centers throughout the southeast region — and expect that trend to continue and perhaps increase,” said Anthony Blanco, director of investment sales for The Shopping Center Group. Mariner's Village, built in 1986 and renovated in 2004, is located three miles southeast of downtown Orlando. It is currently 92 percent leased and is anchored by Winn-Dixie and Walgreens. When's the Fed going to raise rates? It doesn't take much for the Federal Reserve to back away from hints that it might raise interest rates. For years, the Fed has spooked markets with talk of finally raising rates, something it has not done since June 2006. And when the stock market slips on such talk, the Fed backs off. You can see the same pattern continuing this week. "The decision to begin the normalization process at the September FOMC meeting seems less compelling to me than it was a few weeks ago,” Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley told a news conference Wednesday. Bottom line: The Fed is stuck with crisis-era interest rates of zero. Click here to read more from the New York Times. Trending stories from our sister pubs
